s t c 1 9 4 7 6

v e r . 1 . 0  ( 2 0 1 9 )




The Calender of Scripture.


Whearin the Hebru, 
Challdian, Arabian,
Phenician, Syrian, Per­
sian, Greek and Latin names, of 
Nations, Cuntreys, Men,
Weemen, Idols, Cities, Hils, Riuers, 
& of oother places in the holly
Byble mentioned, by order of
letters ar set, and tur­
ned into oour Eng­
lish toong.
1575.

Psal. Lxxxviij.
Nunquid narrabit aliquis in se­
pulchro misericordiam tuam? 
& veritatem tuam in perditio­
ne?












¶ The Printer vnto the gentle Reedar.


AS Gods maiestie in his creation of
mankynde, endued the same amoong 
many other his gratious bodyly gifts, 
with no one thing of more hy price & 
excellency, then with the tool of toong 
for speech & voys, whearby in sort of 
words one to be able so deeply to strike
the conceiuyng of his mynde into the 
vnderstandyng and sens of anoother: euen so at fyrst for vse 
thearof, vouchsafed his goodnes (as Scripture sheawth


Genesis. 2.
 

vs) to bryng al the wyghts he had made of the earth, and al 
the fouls of the ayr, vntoo oour fyrst father, to see and gyue 
them name: that what euer name he gaue them, wear they 
thearby called. Adam (sayth the text) by seuerall name cal­
led al lyuyng creatures, and euery foule of the ayr, and all 
beasts of the earth. Each of them (be we sure) by so apt and 
feet a tearm, touchyng eyther the qualitie, propertie, shape, 
coolour, condition, voys, or sum other such peculiar pro­
priety of the creature named, as whoo so euer could attayn 
but to sum part of the knowledge of those causes, myght 
iustly acknowledge a singuler wisdom in the fyrst Namer, 
and an incomparable mercy in the gyuer of that wisdoom. 
Accordyng vnto which rule this fyrst Namer hym selfe, 
foormed out of ruddy clay, and thearby endued with the pu­
rest of complexions (as we tearm them) Rubicund or 
Sanguine, had hym selfe first to name in the Hebru (the 
fyrst of langages) Adam. As his make beyng the onely


Adam. Rubeus.


wooman at her creation, counted moother and lyfe to all 
posteritie, and (for her breakyng the commaundment) the 
causer also of calamitie and wo, Adam named Eua. Their


Eua mater om­ 
nium viuentium, 
Gene. 3. c.


first sun, for the lands he shoold possess, for the moornyng
he shoold cause, and for the enuie he shoold bear to his 
broother Abel, Adam named Cain. Their second sun, for


Cain. Possessio, 
Inuidia.


the sorow that his death shoold rayse vp to them, he named 
Abel. After this sort was the leader of the Israelites out of


Abel. Luctus.


Egypt, for that he was saued out of the water, called in the 




Egyptian toong Moyses. His broother for his constancie


Moyses. Sump­
tus ex aqua.


and strength in stablishment of the law amoong them, cal­
led a strong Mountayn, in Hebru Aaron. The moother of


Aaron. Mons 
fortis.


oour raunsomer Christ, for the prerogatiue which by that 
byrth abooue all oother, she shoold be blessed withall, was 


Maria. Exaltata.


named Exalted, in Hebru Maria. Her sun our Redeemer
vouchsafed to haue name in remembrauns of his mercy 
Iesus, that is, health or Saluation. His foregoer, for that he 


I E S V S. Salus, 
Saluator.


shoold be Christes messenger, and for the speciall grace 
whearwith he shoold excell, was called Ioannes, which is


Ioannes, domini
gratia.


an Angel, a messenger, or the grace of God. And after this 
rate may it wel be vnto vs a matter not onely not incredi­
ble, but also vndoutable , that all proper names of all things 
in al nations, wear vpon like foundation grounded 
as I finde, out of the Greek, as Agnes, that signifieth a vir­
gin, or chast: Agatha, Good: Andreas, Manly: Alexander, 
a Succorman: Actaeon, a Coastman: sum out of the Latin, 
as Adeodatus, gyuen of God: Albion, oour Cuntrey, so cal­
led of the whyte Cleeues: Agrippa, of a hard byrth: sum 
out of oour auncient brittish, as Apprice, the sun of Rese: 
Aburgeuenny, (short Aburgenny,) the moouth of the ryuer 
Geuenny in Wales: Armoric, vpon the sea, the hither coast 
of Frauns and Flaunders. So haue we out of oour antike 
Saxony (whearvpon our English grewe) this name A­
delmton (which amiss we call Edmonton) that soundeth in 
oour English now, the noble town, or town of noble men: 
 Adelred, (short Aldred) noble counsel: Alboro, olld Town: 
Audley, or rather Adeley, The Princes, or the noble Iland. 
But as all thing ar found to ly so in daunger of obliuions 
dayly ouertreadyng, or at least so to be subiect vnto corrup­
tion or chaunge to the woors, (the very footpath to forget­
fulness) that hard it is to hold the remembrauns of be­
ginnings (though of matters newe) and more hard a great 
deel to fetch out the originall of olld, so yet to bring proper 
Names to the reason and cause of theyr fyrst callyng, and so 
to keep them in memory, diuers learned men at sundry 
tymes and places (I vnderstand) haue sundryly well occu­




pyed them selues. Whearof too in especial for the Names in 
the holy Byble, one called Frauncis Ximenes, sumtyme an 
Archbishop of Tolede in Spayn, the oother of oour days 
now, Iohn Arquery a Bourdeauser. Out of both these (the
one made to supply that the oother waanted) hath thear been 
compounded a perfit Calender according to the title of the 
book: whearin is syrst set the name, then the toong whear­
of it is: then the name expounded into Latin by the one or 
the oother, as best serues: and after put into our English for 
oour Cuntrey, which was the cheef cause of the trauayl 
taken: Lastly is thear added to the woord a note, both of the 
person or thyng what it was, and also of the book and 
chapter whear the same is mentioned. So the commoditie 
of this Calender consydering with my self, how pleasaunt 
for varietee, and profitable for knowledge it mought be vn­
to all: and thearwith how aptly it mought square with 
the trauayle I haue in hand in the reprintyng of oour En­
glish Byble: I could not stay me, but to vse the diligens 
and cunning I could, to get the copy soon into my hand. 
Which as with good curtesy it was deliuered me, so 
thought I it my part agayn, redyly fyrst in this small vo­
lume to impart it vnto you. If ought ye fynde in it more 
profitable then is in the Title vaunted: deem ye as I 
doo, to take that in good part, and the residue to the 
best: for as a gentle ear hartens a good toong, 
so dooth a curteous construction make a wyl­
lyng wryter. Fare ye hartely well in 
Christ, this. ix. of Aprill. 1575. 
Anno regni Reginæ nostræ 
feliciss. xvij.







¶ Authorum, è quorum monumentis, ver­
borum interpretationes, ac Dictionarium suum 
Theologicum contexuit Arquerius, operi suo præposuit 
Catalogum: Quem quò magis tot celebres viros in hoc thematis genere 
operam nauare non pœnituisse, atque quò sedula istius pij homi­
nis industria planè constet, huic quoque opusculo an­
nectere operæpretium videbatur.


Biblia sacrosancta veteris translationis, impressa Venetijs 
apud Iuntas. 1557.
Philonis opera, impressa Basileæ apud Episcopium.
Philonis interpretatio nominum Hebraicorum, Lugduni 
apud Gryphium.
Iosephi opera. Lugduni apud prædictum Gryphium.
Clementis Romani, Lutetiæ apud Nicolaum Chesneau.
Clementis Recognitionum libri, Basileæ apud Cratandrum.
Dionysij Areopagitæ, Coloniæ apud Quentel.
Egesippi, Coloniæ apud Gennepæum.
Iustini Philosophi, Basileæ apud Episcopium.
Irenæi Lugdunensis, Basileæ apud Frobenium.
Clementis Alexandrini, Florentiæ apud Torrentinum.
Tertuliani, Basileæ apud Frobenium.
Origenis, Basileæ apud eundem.
Origenis tomi in Ioannem, Venetijs apud Spinellos.
Hippolyti, Coloniæ apud Cholinum.
Cypriani, Lugduni apud Gryphium.
Arnobij, Basileæ apud Frobenium.
Lactantij, Lugduni apud Gryphium.
Eusebij Cæsariensis, Basileæ apud Henricum Petri.
Eiusdem de locis Hebraicis, Lugduni apud Gryphium.
Athanasij, Basileæ apud Frobenium.
Hilarij Pictauensis, Basileæ apud eundem.
Didimi Alexandrini, Coloniæ apud Ioannem Præl.
Optati Mileuitani, prope Moguntiam apud Behem.
Cyrilli Hierosolymitani, Luteciæ apud Gulielmum Desbois.
Epiphanij, Basileæ apud Winterum.
Ephræm, Coloniæ apud Melchiorem Nouesianum.
Basilij Magni, Basileæ apud Oporinum.




Gregorij Nazianzeni, Basileæ apud Heruagium.
Ambrosij Mediolanensis, Basileæ apud Frobenium.
Maximi, Basileæ apud Henricum Petri.
Gregorij Nisseni, Basileæ apud Episcopium.

apud eundem.

Theodoreti Cyrensis in Paulum, Florentiæ apud Torren­
tinum.
Eiusdem contra aliquot hæreses, &c. Basileæ apud
Oporinum.
Cyrilli Alexandrini, Basileæ apud Heruagium.
Augustini Hipponensis, Basileæ apud Frobenium.
Primasij, Lugduni apud Gryphium.
Paulini Nolani, Coloniæ apud Cholinum.
Vigilij Tridentini, Coloniæ apud Birckmannum.
Ioannis Cassiani, Basileæ apud Cratandrum.
Eucharij Lugdunensis, Basileæ apud Frobenium.
Marci Eremitæ, Luteciæ apud Paruum.
Fulgentij, Basileæ apud Henricum Petri.
Macarij Ægyptij, Luteciæ apud Morelium.
Ioannis Damasceni, Basileæ apud Henricum Petri,
Nicephori Callisti, Basileæ apud Oporinum.
Oecumenij, Basileæ apud Isingrinum.
Canones Consiliorum, Basileæ apud Oporinum.
Gregorius Magnus, Episcopus Romanus.

Cui quidem Arquerij sedulitati, vernaculus hic noster interpres adiecit 
etiam Roberti Stephani (Francisci Francorum Regis Impressoris) ho­
minis de reliter aria optimè meriti: atque Francisci Ximenis Archiepis­
copi Toletani, Præsulis hìc summè industrij, ea Nominum interpreta­
menta quæ aliàs desyderabantur. Quorum ille scripsit, 1540. 
hic autem dum Academiam Complutensem Hispaniarum 
celeberrimam (iuxta Damian. à Goes) in Regne Castilia instituit.








The Calender of Scripture.


Aa.

A Abaoth. Hebraicum. Arquerius. Maxilla: A cheek bone. 
In Hieremia.

Aalee. Aalac. Heb. Arque. Mille: A thousand.
Syr. Diuidens. Leuis. Limpidus: Partyng. Lyght. CL
Mons in Syria.

Aaron. Hebr. Arquer. Mons fortitudinis. Mons fortis.
Mons eorum: A hyll of strength. A myghty hyll. Their hyl.
Ximenes. Mons. Montanus. Docens. Concipiens: A hyll. Hylly. Teaching. Con­
ceiuing. Hic fuit filius Amram, frater Mosis. Exod. 4. 6. Orator & interpres 
Mosis: Exod. 4. 7. Primus Sacerdos summus ad Leuitici sacerdotij administratio­
nem à Deo per Mosen vocatus: Num. 8. Exod. 29. Primum suum sacrificium of­
fert: Num. 9. Moritur: Num. 20.

Aaronitæ. Ximen The same plurally.

Aas bai. Ximen Confidens in me. Frater circundans: Trustyng in 
me. A cumpassing broother.
Hebraicosyrum. Frater senectutis: A broother of age. Filius Machati, genitor 
Eliphelet, fortis fuit Dauidis. 2. Sam. 23.

Aastari. Ximen Cursor. Veredarius. Festinatio turturis aut explora­
toris. Frater qui explorat: A Currer. A post. The haste of the Turtle or of the 
scout. A broother that searcheth out.
Syrohebræum. Princeps turturis. Aut explorationis: Prince of the turtle. Cap­
tayn of the Scoutwatch.

Aathach. Hebr. Arquer. Tempore suo: In his tyme.

Athar. Hebr. Arquer. Deprecatio: Entreaty.

Aaz. Hebr. Arquer. Continens. Apprehendens: Holdyng. Catching.

Aazia. Hebr. Arquer. Apprehendens Dominum. Robur Domini. Fortitu­
do eius: Takyng hold of the Lorde, The Lordes myght. His strength.



Ab.

Abacuc. Habacuc. Heb. Ximen. Luctator. Amplexans: A wreastler. Taking 
hold. Propheta Iudæos consolans, & Christum eis prædicens.

Abaddon. Hebr. Arquer. Perdens: Destroying. Nomen Abyssi. Apocal. 9.

Abadon. Hebr. Ximen. Exterminans. Perditio: Bannishyng. Destruction.

Abana. Hebr. Ximen. Lapideus. Ædificatio. Pater obsecro nunc: Stony. 
Bylding. Father I beseek you now.
Arquer. Lapides eius: His stones of the rock. Fluuius. Damasci. 2. Reg. 5.

Abani. Bani. Heb. Ximen. Filius. Ædificatio. Intelligens: A sun. Bylding. 
Understandyng.

Abarim. Hebr. Arquer. In transitu. Transitus: In passyng by. A passage. 
Ximen. Transitus (pluraliter) Transeuntes. Furores. Prægnantes: Passynge
by. Goers by. Rages. With chylde.
Syrum. Frumenta: Corne. Mons est in quo mortuus Moses. Num. 27. Deut. 32. 
34. Dicitur & mons Nabau.

Abaron. Hebr. Ximen. The same plurally. Frater Iudæ Machabæi, alio nomine




Eleazar. 1. Macha. 2.

Abba. Hebr. Arquer. Pater: Father. 
Syr. Ximen. The same.

Abda. Hebr. Ximen. Seruus. Seruitus: A bondman. Bondage.
Hebrosyrum. Nubes ista: This clooud. Filius Sammua, Leuita in Hierusalem post 
captiuitatem Babylonicam. Neem. 11.

Abdai. Hebr. Ximen. Seruus. Seruitus. Nubes abundans: A slaue. Bondage. A 
very great clooud.

Abdam. Amdam. Hebr. Ximen. Cupiditas. Calor iudicii: Greedy desyre. 
Heat of iudgement.

Abdan. Hebr. Arquer. Desyderabilis: Lykesum. Filius Disan, nepos Sier. Gen. 36.

Abdehel. Adbehel. Hebr. Ximen. Seruus Dei. Vapor. Nubes apud Deum, 
vel cum Deo. Contristari faciens Deus: Gods seruaunt. A moyst fume. A 
clooud with God. God makyng sad. Filius Hismael. Gene. 25.

Abdemelech. Hebr. Arquer. Ximen. Seruus reg is vel Consilii:: The kyngs or 
Counsels seruaunt. Æthiops ille qui Hieremiam liberat è lacu. Hierem. 38.

Abdenago. Hebr. Aquer. Seruiens taceo: I sarue and say nothyng.
Ximen. Seruus claritatis. Seruus anxietatis: The seruaunt of bryghtness. A care­
full seruaunt. Condiscipulus Danielis in Chaldeorum literis: Daniel. 1. Idem in ardente 
fornace diuinitus seruatur. Daniel. 3.

Abdi. Hebr. Ximen. Seruus. Seruitus. Nubes abundans: A seruaunt. Bondage. 
A very great clooud. Leuita temporis Ezechiæ regis. 2. Paral. 29. Filius Elam, 
qui cum alijs Iudæis alienigenas vxores suas repudiauit. Esdr. 10.

Abdias. Hebr. Arquer. Seruus Domini: The Lords man. Propheta contempora­
neus Hieremiæ. Item, dispensator domus Regis Ahab, qui pauit centum prophetas ab­
sconditos in speluncis ne interficerentnr à Iezabel. 1. Reg. 18.

Abdiel. Hebr. Arquer. Seruiens Deo: Saruyng God.
Ximen. Seruus Dei. Nubes abundantiæ Dei: Gods seruaunt. The clooud of 
Gods plenty. Filius Gumi, è tribu Gad. 1. Paral. 5.

Abdon. Hebr. Arquer. Seruus mœroris: The slaue of soro. 
Ximen. Nubes iudicii: The clooud of doom. Iudex populi Israel ex tribu Ephraim. 
Iudi. 12. Item: Consiliarius regis Iosiæ. 2. Paral. 34. Et Ciuitas Leuitarum in tribu 
Aser. Ios. 21.

Abdo. Hebr. Arquer Seruus eius: His bondman.

Abed. Hebr. Arquer. Seruus: A bondman.

Abel. Abela. Hebr. Arquer. Nihil hoc. Luctus. Vanitas. Vapor. Misera­
bilis. Committens. This nothyng. Moornyng. Vanitee. A moist fume, Pitifull. 
Puttyng togyther. 
Ximen. Anhelitus: Breath. Filius Adam & Euæ secundus, ouium pastor. Deum timens, 
à fratre suo Cain in agro occisus. Genes. 4. Item: Oppidum
 in tribu Nephthalim. 
3. Reg. 15. 4. Reg. 15.
Syr. Vapor. Smoke. Abela item Ager vinearum vbi dimicauit Iephte in terra filiorum 
Ammon. Iudic. 11. Alia ciuitas vini fertilis propè Gadarim. Tertia in Phœnice inter 
Damascum, & Paneadem. Euseb. Alia quoque in tribu Nephthalim, in quam confugit




Siba seditiosus. 2. Sam. 20.

Abelmaim. Hebr. Ximen. Luctus aquarum: The moornyng of waters. Ciui­
tas quam Rex Asa per Benhadad, Syrum expugnauit. 2. Paral. 16. 1. Reg. 15.

Abelmeola. Hebr. Arquer. Luctus parturientis: The moorning of the wooman 
in trauell.

Abelmeula. Heb. Ximen. Luctus infirmitatis, aut chori, vel tympani: The 
soroing of weakness, of the cumpany, or of the drum.
Hebrosyr. Luctus veniæ: The monyng for pardon.

Abelsatim. Heb. Spinosus locus: A place full of thorns. Locus in deserto ad Me­
ridiem Moabitaruin. Eusebius de locis Hebraicis.

Abenboem. Heb. Ximen. Lapideus digitus pollicis. Lapis in eis: A thoomb as 
stiff as stone. A stone in them.

Abenezer. Hebr. Arquer. Lapis adiutorii. Lapis auxiliator: The stone of ayd. 
The helping stone. Locus vnde Philistijm tulerunt arcam testamenti, inter Æliam 
& Ascalonem, iuxta villam Bethsamis.

Abenner. Hebr. Arquer. Pater meus lucerna. Pater Lucernæ: My father a 
lyght. The father of torch lyght.

Abelsatim. Hebr. Steph. Luctus spinarum, aut declinationum, vel præuari­
cationum. Vallis vel planicies cedrorum imputribilium: The moorning of 
thorns, of bygoings or of breakyng order. The valley or playn of the vnrotting Ce­
ders. Locus non procul à Iordane in deserto ad Meridiem Moabitarum, à spinartens 
copia nomen habens. Num. 33. f. Ioel. 3. Illic fuit. xlij. mansio Iudæorum.

Aber. Hebr. Arquer. Commisit. Certamen iniit. Particeps: He did put toogy­
ther. He stroue. A parttaker.
Ximen. Socius. Incantator. Liuor: A fello. An enchaunter. Enuy.

Abes. Hebr. Steph. Ouum. Cœnosus. Lineus: An eg. Myery. Lynnen. No­
men Ciuitatis in tribu Issachar. Ios. 19.

Abesalom. Hebr. Ximen. Pater pacis, vel consummationis, aut retributionis. 
Patris pax consummatio vel retributio: The father of peas or of finishing, 
or of rewarding. The peas, perfiting or recompencing of the father. Pater Maa­
cha siue Michai matris Abiam. 3. Reg. 15. Qui 2. Paral. 13. Dicitur Vriel. Steph.

Abesan. Heb. Ximen Patris scutum vel arma. Pater frigiditatis: The fathers 
sheeld or weapons, the father of coldness. Nomen Iudicis in Israel de Bethlehem. 
Iudic. 12. c.

Abesatim. Heb. Arquer. Luctus littorum, vel riparum: The lamentyng of the 
sea shores, or of the ryuer banks.

Abetharim. Hebr. Arquer. Via exploratorum: The wey of the Skouts.

Abgam. Hebr. Arquer. Pater sordis: The father of
 fylth.

Abgatha Hebr. Ximen. Pater torcularis. Patris torcular: The father of the 
press. The fathers press. Eunuchus Assueri Regis Persarum.
Esther. 1. b.

Abi. Ithai. Hebr. Ximen. Hora. Tempus. Paratus: An oour. Tyme. Reddy. 
Steph. Pater meus: My father. Mater Ezechiæ regis. 4. Reg. 18. Quæ 2. Par. 29. a. 
dicitur Abia.

Abia. Hebr. Arquer. Pater meus iuste. Patris mei abundantia. Pater domi­




nus. Pater fuit: My father in deed. My fathers plenty. Father Lord. The father 
was. Rex Iudæ. 1. Reg. 14. 2. Paral. 13. Matth. 1. Alius, filius Samuelis. 1. 
Sam. 18. Item filius Ieroboam. 1. Reg. 14. Alius, Sacerdos Dauidis. 1. Para. 14. 
Alius, Sacerdos. Nehem. 12. Item vxor Esrom. 1. Paral. 2. Filia Zachariæ. 2. 
Reg. 18. 2. Paral. 29.

Abiaiel. Abiail. Hebr. Ximen. Pater fortitudinis, vel exercitus, aut 
diuitiarum. Pater ante muralis, vel doloris: Father of strength, of the host, 
or of rychess. A vaunt mure or forewall father. Father of greef.

Abialbon. Abiel. Hebr. Arquer. Pater meus superintelligens: My father 
of hy vnderstandyng. Arbathites. 2. Sam. 23. 1. Paral. 11. 
Heb. Syr. Pater iniuriæ: The father of wrong. Nomen viri. 2. Reg. 23. d. Qui 
Paral. 1. Ca. 11. f. dicitur Abiel. Steph.

Abiam. Hebr. Ximen. Pater, vel voluntas domini. Pater maris: The father, 
or will of the lorde. The father of the sea. Filius Roboam. 3. Reg. 14. g. 15. a. Qui 
& Abia. 1. Paral. 3. b. dicitur Steph.

Abias. Heb. Arquer. Veniens. Patris mei hic: Cummyng. Of my father heer.

Abiasab. Abiasaph. Heb. Ximen. Pater congregans, consummuns, vel fi­
niens: A father flockyng togeather, parfiting or finishing. Filius Core. 1. Par. 6. c. 
9. c. Exod. 6. d. Filius Elcanæ. 1. Paral. 6. b. 9. c. Steph.

Abiasaph. Also Arquer. Congregatio patris. Patris mei collectio: The fa­
thers 
assemblyng. The gathering toogyther of my father. A quo filij Core sunt orti, 
quorum crebra ad psalmos mentio.

Abiasar. Heb. Arquer. Patris mei collectio: My
fathers gatheryng.

Abiathar. Heb. Arquer. Pater superfluus: The ouerfloing father. 
Ximen. Pater excellens. Pater residui, remanentis, explorationis, contem­
plationis, aut funiculi: An excellent father. The father of the residu, or rem­
naunt, or of search, or of beholdyng, or of the corde. Sacerdos, filius Abimelech. 1. 
Sam. 22. 23. 1. Reg. 22. d.

Abida. Heb. Ximen. Pater scientiæ. Scientia patris: A father of knowledge. The 
fathers skyll. Filius Madiam, nepos Abrahæ. Gen. 25.

Abidan. Heb. Ximen. Pater iudicii: The father of iudgement. 
Heb. Syr. Pater meus iste: This my father. 
Arquer. Pater meus iudex: My father iudge. Filius Gedeonis. Num. 1. a. 

Abiel. Hebr. Arquer. Pater meus Deus: My father God. Auus Saulis regis, 
1. Sam. 9. 
Steph. Filius Seror. 1. Reg. 9. a. Pater Ner. 1. Reg. 14. g. Nomen item alterius. 1. Para. 
11. f. qui 2. Reg. 23. d. dicitur Abialbon.

Abidahe. Hebr. Arquer. Pater meus sciens: My skylfull father.

Abiezer. Hebr. Arquer. Patris mei auxilium: My fathers healp. 
Ximen. Pater adiutorii. Patris adiutorium vel atrium. Frater adiutorii. Fra­
tris adiutorium vel atrium: The father of succour. The fathers ayd or porch. 
A broother of healp. The broothers ayd or vtter coourt. Anathothites è filijs Iemini.

Agrippa. Heb. Arq. Congregans: Soon assemblyng. --- Latin. Ab ægro partu,




qualem efficiunt qui per pedes non per caput, antrorsum in ortu pro­
deunt: They that are born with theyr feet forward. --- Postremus Iudæorum Rex, sub 
quo Hierosolyma à Tito euersa. --- Coram eo Paulus accusatus sistitur. Act. 25. --- 26.

Anathema. Hebraicum. Et propriè Iudæorum verbum: quo quod Deo dicatum 
reseruatur, significant: & vice versa, quod à Deo vel ab ecclesia ab aliena­
tur separatur, & abrumpitur. Fugiendum vtrunque: A thyng reserued, as 
beyng dedicate vntoo God: And contrary wyse, that is turned awey seauered and 
broken of from God, or the church. So both to be shund. --- Chrisost. 16. --- ad Rom.

non euitantes, proni preæcipitesque in mortem ruunt: Suche as nothyng 
repent them of theyr sinnyng, nor feelyng theyr oun destruction, lyke brute beasts 
which though see the swoord, yet stay not too run vpon their oun death. --- Hieron. in 
4. ad Ephes.

Bithynia. Heb. Arq. Filia speciosa vel inutilis. Virguncula. Filia Domi­

Caesar. Heb. Arq. Possessio principalis: The chief hauing in vse.
Latin. A caeso matris vtero vnde excisus, vel à Caefarie: aut (vt nonnulli) 
 à caesijs (id est) à glaucis oculis: Cut oout of the moochers woomb. As it is 
written that Caius Iulius Caesar was, whoo first amoong the Romayns, took Em­
pyre vpon him. And from him all Emperours syns called Caesars: --- Matth. 22. b.--­
Vnde vna Caesarea Palestinæ: quondam Turris strationis dicta: Ioseph. lib. 1. Belli Iu­
daic. Cap. 3. & 16. --- Plin. li. 1. ca. 13. --- Act. 9. 10. 12. & 21. --- Alia ad radices Libani iuxta

tropolis Capadociæ: Act. 18. b.

Cariatharbe. Hebr. Arquer. Villula quatuor: The hamlet or foour.
Xim. Ciuitas quatuor (scilicet) patriarcharum, videlicet, Adam, Abraam,

à quatuor patriarchis ibi sepultis: Ios. 15--20. c.

bita: He had a cittee. A cittee had.

Chanaan. Chamaan. Heb. Arq. Reuersus est. Quasi respondentes. Quasi mo­

uing. Blusshing. An occupier.
Xim. Mercator. Negotiator. Contritus. Confractus. Recte respondens. Recte

aunswering. Well chastising (and these aswell masculine as feminine.) A dwellyng.

tinuit terram à Sidone, vsque ad Gasam. Quam postea Iudaei eiectis Chananaeis possederunt:

Xim. Voluptuosus. Testificans vel deglutiens iudicium: Gyuen too plea­
sures. Witnessyng or swalloing vp of iudgement.
Syr. Temporalis: For the tyme. --- Filius Iacob ex Bala ancilla Rachelis: Gene. 30.

DEVS. Lat. Arq. ἑ Græco. παρἁ τἡν θἑσιν, hoc est. Ex positione. Ordine 
& Administratione: God hauing name oout of the greek. Of setting. Of ordring.




And appoyntyng. Drels. --- Δἱα τὸτεθεικἐναι id est, Ab eo quòd omnia in suam 
securitatem collocet: Puttyng all thyng vnder his safty. Vel ab ἁ θεἴν id est, 
A currendo, quòd omnia mouendo in operationem producat: Makyng all 
thyng too exercise by naturall moouyng. Vel ab Αἴθεἶν id est vrere, Vt qui ignis 
sit omnem malitiam consumens: A fyre consumyng all that is ill. Aut à Θεἆσθαι 
id est, Ab intuendo omnia, vt quem nihil latere possit: Beholldyng all, as 
from whoom nothyng can be hydden. God is called in Hebru, Sabaoth, id est, 
Voluntarium, Dominus copiarum, exercituum, virtutum: A wyllyng, The Lord 
of armyes, of hosts, of vertuze. Eloæ, id est, Deus: God. Adonai, id est, Ad­
mirabile. Qui est Deus: Woonderfull. He that is God. Addonei, id est, Præsi­
niens (scilieet) terram ab aqua: Booundyng oout the land from the water. Iaoth, 
id est, Mensura praefinita. Dator fugæ malorum: A measure before appoynted. 
The causer of flyght to the ill. --- Pater omnium. Altissimus Dominus coelorum. Creator. 
Fabricator. --- Eli, id est, Deus: God. Eloim, id est, Deus semper: God allweys. 
El. Deus. Fortis: God. Strong. Aia, id est, Is qui est: He that is. Saddai. Suffi­
ciens. Potens: Able. Myghty. Elion. Altissimus: Highest. Rabboni. Dominus: 
Ia. Dominus. Iabe. Qui erat, qui est, & semper est: That was, that is, & euer is.
Eloth. Deus: God. --- Allso God is called Spiritus. Ignis. Lux. Vnguentum fragrans. 
Lapis angularis. Pardus. Leo. Vrsa saeuiens. Vermis. Ego sum qui sum. Vita. Lux. Veritas. 
Opifex. Creator. Imperator. &c. in Arquerio.



Di.

Diabolus. Heb. Arq. Defluens Deorsum fluens. Clausus in ergastulis, vel in

Græc. Xim. Criminator. Calumniator. Accusator: A quareller. A challenger.

Diana. Latin. Xim. A die. Quòd splendeat luce diei æmula: The moon, 
hauyng name of the day: for that it gyues a lyght counterfeytyng the daylyght.
Iouis & Latonæ filia, vno partu cum Appolline ædita. Cui nomina: Luna. Lucina. Proser­
pina. Hecate. Triuia. Cuius & mentio: Act. 19. --- Templum habuit Ephesi magnificentiss.
Plin. lib. 36. cap. 14. --- Lib. 16. cap. 40. --- Vt quam summè Ephesij colebant.

suo ibidem prologo) apud Hebræos liber sit tantum vnicus. --- See Dibreiamim.

Elioenai. Heb. Ximen. Ad Dominum oculi mei. Deus ipse ocu­
lorum meorum. Ad ipsum oculi mei, vel fontes mei. Ad ipsum af­
flictio vel paupertas: Myne eys vntoo the Lord. God him self of myne 
eys. Too him myne eys, or my wells. Too him my trooble or poouertie.

Iesbidenob. Iesbibenob. Heb. Xi. Sedens in prophetia, in locutione, germinatione.

in buddyng. Turning or puffing vp in prophezy, speech, or springyng. Subduing

Anna, grace. Grace from God. It is grace from God. Gods grace. Ioannes Bapt. fi­

Israel. Heb. Arq. Est videre Deum. Vir, aut mens videns Deum. Rectus

tentiam. Isra enim, homo. El, potentia. Xim. Præualens. Dominans cum 
Deo: Is too see God. A man, or mind seeing God. The Lords perfit one. A man
behollding God. Striuing agaynst the holly angell. A man ouercumming poour.
For Isra, signifieth, A man, and El, Pour. Hauing the better. Hauing rule by God.

him that is named or set. The pretious stone Lincurius, which we call Aumber.
Vrbs quam filij Dan capiontes nominarunt Dan: Ios. 19. d --- Quæ & Lais dicta. Hæc à 
Philippo Tetrarcha senioris Herodis silia, in bonorem Tiberij, Caesarea Philippi appella­
ta. Vulgò à Barbaris nunc Belina. De lapide autem Lincurio: Exod. 28. c.

vnc. pro modio per Iun. Et Lethec à Iudaeis vocatum, quòd possit ab adolescente leuari,

a pek, and a poound weyght of oour measure.

Metreta. Græc. Mensura: A measure. --- Et diuisa in Syriacam, quæ capit Sex­
tarios 120. hoc est 180. libras. Three of oour busshels and a pek within too poound. Et 
Atticam quæ est 72. Sextariorum, librarum (scilicet) 108. Too busshels lacking hallf a 
pek, and hallf a poound. --- Hanc recenset Arquerius ad rationem mensuræ sanctae. Sed 
quoniam tria ea sata similæ: Gen. 18. a. Quæ Abraham Angelis in subcineritium panem 
praeparari iussit (ad fesquimodium in Satum hoc est, 40. libras) constabant. 120. libris, quæ 
proportio erat. Too busshells, a pek and a poound: Et fuerint interim qui tradiderint 
eatria sata Metretas tres fuisse: differentiam annotare, atque eiusdem leclores ammonere, 
non indignum videbatur. --- See more in Satum.

Moyses. Heb. Arq Attrectans. Palpans. Sumptus ex aqua. Assumptio. 
Assumptus. Contrectans. Vrgens. Ex aqua. Tentatio Dei, & inuentio:
Feeling. Groping. Taken oout of the water. A taking vp. Taken vp. Handeling. 
Pressing. Oout of the water. Gods moouing, and finding.

Moyses. Though it haue been receyued an Hebru woord, yet sproong 
it fyrst oout of the Egyptian toong. Whear Moy signifyeth water and Elis sa­
ued. That because he was saued oout of the water (whear els he had been dround) 
he was by the Queen calld Moyses, that is, saued oout of the water.
Arquer. Ibidem, Mosen vocant eum, qui ex aqua emersus respirauit: They
call him Moyses, that scaping oout of the water, gat him breath agayn. Ioseph. li. 2. 
cap 9. Antiquitat. --- Filius Amram, nepos Caath, filij Leui: Exod. 6. Nascitur --- ibid. 2. 
Vocatur ad suum ministerium: Ibid. 3 --- Instituit Pascha. Ibid. 12 --- Educit Israelitas per 
mare rubrum ibid. 14. --- Producit aquam de petra: ibid. 17. --- Accepit a Deo legem in mon­
te Sina ibid. 20. Et deinceps, Instituit sacrificia in Leuitico. Repetit legem in Deutero­
nomio. Moritur, Deut. 34. --- Psal. 89. Act. 7.

dinis vt coelum contingere videatur: qui hinc nonnunquam à poêtis pro coelo ipso poni­
tur. Quæ etiam propter Gymnica certamina quinto quoque anno eo in monte celebrari




solita, quinque annorum spatium apud Græcos Olympias, quod apud Romanos alia ratio­
ne lustrum est appellata. Quidam tamen Olympiadem quatuor tantum annorum tempus 
constituunt, sed (vt ait Bibliander) exactior indicatura ponit annos quinque. All one 
(per Steph.) as Olympas: Rom. 16. h.

secretum, & in alto situm: vsque ad lunarem circulum pertingentem, vnde nec aquæ diluuij
illuc peruenerunt. Aliàs: Paradysus terrestris, est in extremis finibus Orientis, &

Phytona. Heb. Arq. Os abyssi: The moouth of the bottomles pit. --- Phyton,
(inquit Arquerius) est Diabolus respondens interrogantibus: A familiar: Qualem ha­
buisse eam mulierem Endorensem (hinc Phytonissa dicta) sacra scriptura tradit, quae
Sauli, sui, suorumque cladem, tristem belli euentum praenunciauit: 1. Reg. 28. a. b. --- Iose­
phus de istiusmodi scribit, eas genus ventriloquorum esse, per quas euocando mortuorum
animas futura poscentibus praedici soleant: li. 6. ca. 14. vbi summis interea laudib. Saulis
magnanimitatem hoc nomine depraedicat: quòd interitum suum certò licet praesciens,
neque reditum ad suos detrectauit, neque praesentia vspiam eos destituit, vsque dum for­
tunam ad extremum expertus, fortis fortiter vnà conciderit.

Psalmus. Græc. Canticum: A godly song. --- Ode Musa vel hymnus in
laudes, in gratiarum actiones vel supplicationes Deo composita: cuiusmodi centum & quinquaginta
composuit Rex & Propheta ille Dauid in vnum volumen, quod Psalterium vocatum.

Psalterium. Græc. Quod Hebraice Nablon dictum, Latinè Organum laudatorium, ob
decem suas chordas Decachordum etiam vocatum, in modum quadrati clypei confectum,
nostro orbi inusitatum. Ad quod cecinit suos Psalmos Dauid. A musicall instrument
often strings. A Sautry.

Pseudopropheta. Græc. Falsus vates: A fals prophet. --- Qui non sunt audiendi: Deut.
3. a --- 18 d

Psonphtonfanicos. Græc. Xim. Absconditorum inuentor: A fynderoout or de­
uiser of secrets: Ioseph. li. 2. antiquitat. Iudaic.


Pt.

Ptolomaida. Græc. Xim. Bellicosa: Full of war.

Ptolomais. The same. Heb. Arq. Allso. Deducens ad mensuram: Leadyng too
measure. --- Ciuitas Iudaeæ, maritima, propè Carmelum montem à quodam Ptolomæono­
minata. Est & altera in Pentapoli, prouincia Aphricæ: Act. 21. b

Ptolomai. The same plurally.

Ptolomenses. The same.

Ptolomæus. Heb. Xim. Sulcus. Suspendens aquas aut coadunatio aquarum:
A plooughfurro. Penning vp the water, or makyng waters too meet.
Græc. Bellicosus: Valiaunt. --- Filius Dorymini: 1. Macch. 3. e --- Item Ptolomæus Phi­
lometor, Ægypti Rex: 1. Macch. 1-2. Macch. 4 --- Item Ptolomæus Simonis sacerdotis
& Iudaeorum princeps, praefectus regioni Hierichuntinæ, qui dolo inter fecit socerum: 1.
Macch. 16 --- Quidam etiam aulicus Antiochi Epiphanis: 2. Macch. 4.

"plooughfurro" antedates the earliest OED citation of "plough furrow" (n.; 1597).

triduò hospitatus Paulus, patrem decumbentem sanauit: Act. 28.

ryng of fat.

Qu.

QVartus. Heb. Arq. Plangens, vel superfluè: Moornyng, or not needfully.
Latin. Fourth. --- Vir quidam: Rom. 16. d

Quadrans. Latin. Nummus exiguus, atque idem (ex Euangelio) quod
duo minuta. Too mytes. Viginti quatuor autem minuta apud Flan­
dros pendent ex denarijs nostris, vnum: So as Quadrans may be after
the rate of oour money, the twelfth part of oour penny. --- Marc. 12. d --- Sunt autem
qui traduc ant Quadrantem ad quartam denarij partem, vt constet minutis Flandricis
sex. Iunius in suo Nomenclatore.

Quintus. Latin. The fyfth (by lyke) in byrth. --- Quintus Memius Legatus Roma­
norum: 2. Macch. 11.

Sabbatum secundo primum. Latin. (After oour common translation) On an Af­
ter principall Sabot. --- Omne festum apud Iudæos Sahbatum vocabatur. Quando verò
aliud festum superueniebat commune ebdomadæ Sabbatum in vnum eundemque cadens
diem, (vt per Parasceuen & aliàs saepè fiebat) sicuti illud Superueniens Festum Sabba­
tum appellab atur, it a propriè tunc Sabbatum secundò primum vocabant: Chrisost. Hom. 
40. in Matth. --- Item, Theophil. in Luc. 6. a.

Sabbati vna. Latin. vel Sabbati prima: The fyrst Sabot. The fyrst day of the
week that is noow oour Sabbot day, (Sunday) Ob quas rationes, vide nomen Eli­
zabeth. --- Iudaei autem integram hebdomadam in vnum Sabbatum concludebant: sub­
diuidentes dies in primam Sabbati (qui est noster Dominicus dies) deinde per ordinem in
secundam, tertiam, quartam, quintam, & sextam: quam Ethnici & alij hos secuti, Idolo­




rum & elementorum nominib. appellant: Hieron. Hedibiae. --- Matth. 28. a --- Marc. 16. a. 
Luc. 24. a. --- Ioan. 20. a

Remembring. The male.

Sacrilegium. Latin. A Sacra legendo: The aft of holly or halloed things --- Sacri­
legium propriè in Deum committitur, & est quasi sacrosancti violatio. Hieron, in 2. ad 
Roman. --- Qui ex lege & Prophetis sermonem Christum pronunciantem furatur & oc­
cultat nè populus audiat & credat, sacrilegium committit: Et verè Dei templum violat: 
Origenes lib. 2. ad Rom. --- Quòd si etiam, vt nonnunquam fieri solet, munera oblata Deo, 
& stipem in vsus pauperum datam, ad propria lucra quis conuerterit, rectè ei dicitur: 
Qui abominaris Idola, sacrilegium facis: Idem. Ibidem.

Latin "Cyrogrillus" appears to be a squirrel. See Hya Dines, "The Textual and Pictorial Metamorphoses of the 
Animal called Cirogrillus," Science Translated, ed. Michèle Goyens and Pieter de Leemans (2008): 73-91. However, the Englished equivalent, "portepyke", must be a porcupine.

seph. li. 3. ca. 2. --- ab Amri rege Israelitico constructa, qui montem eum à quodam Semer

Sau. Sauhe. Heb. Arq. Dignè. Eleuatio: Woorthyly. Lyftyng vp.

A slaunder. A displeasure. --- Origen. li. 9. ad Roman.

gressus de Mesopotamia. Euseb.

grauis ecclesiæ fieret, exercuit Paulus: Act. 18. a

Leuit. 23 --- Ioan. 7. a

Schibboleth. Heb. Steph. Spica. Fluctus aquarum: An ear of corn. Waues. 
 --- Iudic. 12. c

Schipes. Græc. Culex estin aêre suspensa volitans, corporetam exili, vt oculi 
acumen nisi perspicacissimè cernentis facilè fallat: cutem autem quæ feriat 
stimulo terebrat acerrimo: subtilitate & acumine tanto, vt quam volitan­
tem conspicere nequeas pungentem ex ictu sentias: This Scnipes is a 
kynd of gnat flittering in the ayr, that stays vp it self by the wyngs: of substauns so
fyne and small, as but by the ey of a sharp syght, it can not be discerned: any part of 
the body yet if it light vpon: with so sharp a styng dooth it pears, as which whoo sees 


Origen. Ho­
mil. 4. in. 
Exod.


not in flying, shall feel in smartyng. This note is taken oout of Origens writings,
whoo was born at Adamantia in Grees, in which cuntree this kynd of gnat shoold 
seem too be: heer for the straungenes rehersed. --- De Scnipe etiam Aristot. Hist. li. 8. ca. 3. 

Scribae. Latin. Writers. --- De quorum professione vide hic post, in Sedere super 
cathedram Moysi.

Secta. Latin. A cumpany of one profession and opinion in learning or Reli­
gion. And called Secta, of Sector (folloing) as folloing sum cheef teacher, or of 
Sectus (cut of) as parted and seueared from the common sens of others --- Sectæ au­

sunt enisi, fuere Tres: Pharisaeorum, Sadducaeorum, & Essenorum, qui & Osij (id est 
sancti) vocati: Et Esseni dicti ab honestate vitæ: Chrisost. Homil. 46. in Act. De diuer­

Sethim. Heb. Arq. Spinae. Xim. Expansiones. Diuertentes. Flagella: Thorns. 
Spreadyngs abrode. Turnyng asyde. Scoorges. Locus in campestribus Moab, non 
procul a Iordane & monte Phogor: vnde Iosue emisit exploratores ad inuestigandum 
Ierichontis terram: Num. 25. a --- See Sitim. --- Ligna Sethim, quorum in Exodo crebra 
mentio, ex arborib. fiunt spinæ albæ tum colore tum folijs similib. (hoc est) folijs, maculis 
albis aspersis. Tam grandes autem crescunt, vt latissima ex eis tabulata caedantur, & for­
tissima: leuitatis insuper ac pulcbritudinis incredibilis. Hieronimus in Ioelem.

Regali Hispanico nostri temporis. So was their syluer Siclus aboout too shyllings 
& too pens of oour syluer moony noow, weyd hallf an oouns lacking a grote, that is 
the fyfteenth part of oour oounce. Ioseph. li. 3. Antiquit. ca. 12 --- Ezech. 45. d. The 
too earlings then of golld of two sicles weyght wear woorth a 52. shillings. And 
the too bracelets of ten sicles, woorth a 23. li. which Abrahams steward gaue too
Rebecca. Gen. 24. c

Zomim. Zomzomim. Heb. Xim. Scelus vel turpitudinem cogitantes. Scelus 
sceleratorum: Musing a mischeef or fylthynes. The fooul act of the shamefull




Gigantes fuerunt quos Moabitæ à sua regione expulerunt: Hoc vocabulum non est eo­
rum proprium nomen, sed terribiles & horrendos sonat. Qui populi truces fuerunt Ra­
phaim, a Moabitis Emim, ab Ammonitis Zomzommim dicti: Deut. 2. c --- Gene. 14. a

Zorobabel. Heb. Arq. Princeps vel Magister Babylonis. Aliena transla­
tio. Ortus in Babylone. Ipse magister Babylonis, id est, confusionis. Flui­
tio postposita. Ex commixtione. Hic Doctor Babyloniae. Xim. Alienus 
a confusione. Aliena, vel extranea confusio. Extranea commixtio, aut dis­
persio confusionis vel commixtionis. Circulus commixtionis vel confu­
sionis: A prins or Master of Babylon. A forreyn carrying awey. Born in Babylon. 
He a master in Babilon (that is) confusion. A floing set behind. Of mingling. This 
teacher of Babylon. Far from confusion. A straunge or queint mingling. A straunge
mingling, or sprinkling abrode, of pooring or mingling togyther. The rundel of 
mingling or pooring togyther. Filius Salathiel, nepos Ieconiæ Regis, qui vnà cum Iesu 
Pontifice populum captiuum à Babylone reduxit, vrbem Ierusalem & Templum instau­
rare coepit: 1. Esd. 3 --- 5. Agg. 1. a. & 2. --- Zachar. 4 --- Filius Phadaia filij Iechoniæ: 1. Par. 
3. c. --- 1. Esdr. 2. a --- Ortus ex posteritate Nathan, filij Dauid: Luc. 3.

Zozomim. Heb. Arq. Hæ cogitationes. Quæ est hæc aqua? In acie praepa­
rati: These thoughts. What water is this? Reddy in the forefrunt. --- See Zoho­
mim and Zomim.


Zu.

Zuzim. Heb. Arq. Postes. Columnae. Superluminaria. Splendentes. 
Vphollders. Pillers. Ouerthresshollds. Shining. 
Syr. Recedentes. Pecuniæ: Gooing bak. Moony. --- Ebræum epitheton Nobili­
um: Gene. 14.







Per Summum, Solum, Fortem, Potentem, Vnicum, Viuentem, Iustum, 
Misericordem, DEVM, præter quem non est Deus: Cui soli 
in Maiestate trina, honor, gloria, laus, & gratiarum actio.

FINIS.
